Buckminster Fuller</strong>, in full <strong>Richard Buckminster Fuller</strong>,  (born July 12, 1895, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Milton-Massachusetts" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Milton</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Massachusetts" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Massachusetts</a>, U.S.—died July 1, 1983, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Los-Angeles-California" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Los Angeles</a>, California), American engineer, architect, and futurist who developed the <span id="ref197764"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/geodesic-dome" class="md-crosslink">geodesic dome</a>—the only large dome that can be set directly on the ground as a complete structure and the only practical kind of building that has no limiting dimensions (i.e., beyond which the structural strength must be insufficient). Among the most noteworthy geodesic domes is the United States pavilion for <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/Expo-67" class="md-crosslink">Expo 67</a> in <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Montreal" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Montreal</a>. Also a poet and a philosopher, Fuller was noted for unorthodox ideas on global issues.</p><!--[P1]--><!--[ML1]--></section><!--[H2]--><section id="ref2523" data-level="1"><h2 class="h1">Life</h2><p><span id="ref197765"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Margaret-Fuller" class="md-crosslink">Fuller</a> was descended from a long line of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/New-England" class="md-crosslink autoxref">New England</a> <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Nonconformists" class="md-crosslink">Nonconformists</a>, the most famous of whom was his great-aunt, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Margaret-Fuller" class="md-crosslink">Margaret Fuller</a>, the critic, teacher, woman of letters and cofounder of <em>The Dial</em>, organ of the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/Transcendentalism-American-movement" class="md-crosslink">Transcendentalist</a> movement. Fuller was twice expelled from <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Harvard-University" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Harvard University</a> and never completed his formal education. He saw service in the U.S. Navy during <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/World-War-I" class="md-crosslink autoxref">World War I</a> as commander of a crash-boat flotilla. In 1917 he married Anne Hewlett, daughter of <span id="ref197766"></span>James Monroe Hewlett, a well-known architect and muralist. Hewlett had invented a modular <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/construction-technology" class="md-crosslink autoxref">construction</a> system using a compressed fibre block, and after the war Fuller and Hewlett formed a construction company that used this material (later known as Soundex, a Celotex product) in modules for <span id="ref197768"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/house-dwelling" class="md-crosslink">house</a> construction. In this operation Fuller himself supervised the erection of several hundred houses.</p><!--[P2]--><p>The construction company encountered financial difficulties in 1927, and Fuller, a minority stockholder, was forced out. He found himself stranded in Chicago, without income, alienated, dismayed, confused. At this point in his life, Fuller resolved to devote his remaining years to a nonprofit search for <span id="ref197769"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/design-arts-and-technology" class="md-crosslink">design</a> patterns that could maximize the social uses of the world’s energy resources and evolving industrial complex. The inventions, discoveries, and economic strategies that followed were <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/interim" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="interim">interim</a> factors related to that end.</p><!--[P3]--><p>In 1927, in the course of the development of his <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/comprehensive" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="comprehensive">comprehensive</a> strategy, he invented and demonstrated a factory-assembled, air-deliverable house, later called the <span id="ref197770"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/Dymaxion-house" class="md-crosslink">Dymaxion house</a>, which had its own utilities. He designed in 1928, and manufactured in 1933, the first <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/prototype" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="prototype">prototype</a> of his three-wheeled omnidirectional vehicle, the <span id="ref197771"></span>Dymaxion car. This <span id="ref197772"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/automobile" class="md-crosslink">automobile</a>, the first streamlined car, could cross open fields like a <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/jeep" class="md-crosslink">jeep</a>, accelerate to 120 miles (190 km) per hour, make a 180-degree turn in its own length, carry 12 passengers, and average 28 miles per gallon (12 km per litre) of gasoline. In 1943, at the request of the industrialist <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Henry-J-Kaiser" class="md-crosslink">Henry Kaiser</a>, Fuller developed a new version of the Dymaxion car that was planned to be powered by three separate air-cooled engines, each coupled to its own wheel by a variable fluid drive. The projected 1943 Dymaxion, like its predecessor, was never commercially produced.</p><!--[P4]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="15922"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/59/13759-004-26924FE7.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/59/13759-004-26924FE7.jpg" alt="Buckminster Fuller with his Dymaxion Dwelling Machine, 1930." data-width="390" data-height="300"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Buckminster Fuller with his Dymaxion Dwelling Machine, 1930.</span><cite>© Bettmann/Corbis</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML4]--><p>Assuming that there is in nature a vectorial, or directionally oriented, system of forces that provides maximum strength with minimum structures, as is the case in the nested tetrahedron lattices of organic <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/compounds" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="compounds">compounds</a> and of metals, Fuller developed a vectorial system of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/geometry" class="md-crosslink autoxref">geometry</a> that he called “<span id="ref197773"></span>Energetic-Synergetic geometry.” The basic unit of this system is the <span id="ref197774"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/tetrahedron" class="md-crosslink">tetrahedron</a> (a pyramid shape with four sides, including the base), which, in combination with octahedrons (eight-sided shapes), forms the most economic space-filling structures. The architectural consequence of the use of this geometry by Fuller was the geodesic dome, a frame the total strength of which increases in logarithmic ratio to its size. Many thousands of geodesic domes have been erected in various parts of the world, the most publicized of which was the United States exhibition dome at <span id="ref197775"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/Expo-67" class="md-crosslink">Expo 67</a> in Montreal. One houses the tropical exhibit area of the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Missouri-Botanical-Garden" class="md-crosslink">Missouri Botanical Garden</a> in St. Louis, Another, the <span id="ref197776"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Union-Tank-Car-Company" class="md-crosslink">Union Tank Car Company’s</a> dome, was built in 1958 in <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Baton-Rouge" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Baton Rouge</a>, Louisiana, and, at the time of its construction, was the largest clear-span structure in existence, 384 feet (117 metres) in diameter and 116 feet (35 metres) in height.</p><!--[P5]--><ul class="assemblies medialist" data-type="other"><li><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="124096"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/56/121356-004-88FBDBC9.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/56/121356-004-88FBDBC9.jpg" alt="geodesic dome" data-width="550" data-height="379"></div></div><figcaption><strong class="md-assembly-title">geodesic dome</strong><span class="md-assembly-caption">The Climatron geodesic dome, Missouri Botanical Garden, St. Louis.</span><cite>© ksteffens/iStock.com</cite></figcaption></figure></li><li><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="15928"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/66/13766-004-9148FC78.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/66/13766-004-9148FC78.jpg" alt="The U.S. exhibition dome at Expo 67 in Montreal; designed by Buckminster Fuller." data-width="391" data-height="300"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">The U.S. exhibition dome at Expo 67 in Montreal; designed by Buckminster Fuller.</span><cite>© Lee Snider/Corbis</cite></figcaption></figure></li></ul><!--[ML5]--><p>Other inventions and developments by Fuller included a system of <span id="ref197777"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/cartography" class="md-crosslink">cartography</a> that presents all the land areas of the world without significant distortion; die-stamped <span id="ref197767"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/prefabrication" class="md-crosslink">prefabricated</a> bathrooms; tetrahedronal floating cities; underwater geodesic-domed farms; and expendable paper domes. Fuller did not regard himself as an inventor or an architect, however. All of his developments, in his view, were accidental or interim incidents in a strategy that aimed at a radical solution of world problems by finding the means to do more with less.</p><!--[P6]--><p>Comprehensive and anticipatory design <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/initiative" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="initiative">initiative</a> alone, he held—exclusive of politics and political theory—can solve the problems of human shelter, nutrition, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/transportation-technology" class="md-crosslink autoxref">transportation</a>, and pollution; and it can solve these with a fraction of the materials now <span id="ref197778"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/efficiency-physics" class="md-crosslink">inefficiently</a> used. Moreover, energy, ever more available, directed by <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/cumulative" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="cumulative">cumulative</a> information stored in computers, is capable of synthesizing raw materials, of machining and packaging commodities, and of supplying the physical needs of the total global population.</p><!--[P7]--><p>Fuller was a research professor at <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Southern-Illinois-University" class="md-crosslink">Southern Illinois University</a> (Carbondale) from 1959 to 1968. In 1968 he was named university professor, in 1972 distinguished university professor, and in 1975 university professor emeritus. Queen <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Elizabeth-II" class="md-crosslink">Elizabeth II</a> awarded Fuller the Royal Gold Medal for Architecture. He also received the 1968 Gold Medal Award of the National Institute of Arts and Letters.</p><!--[P8]--></section><!--[H3]--><section id="ref2524" data-level="1"><h2 class="h1">Legacy</h2><p>Fuller—architect, engineer, inventor, philosopher, author, cartographer, geometrician, futurist, teacher, and poet—established a reputation as one of the most original thinkers of the second half of the 20th century. He conceived of man as a passenger in a cosmic spaceship—a passenger whose only wealth consists in <span id="ref197779"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/energy" class="md-crosslink">energy</a> and information. Energy has two phases—associative (as atomic and molecule structures) and dissociative (as radiation)—and, according to the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/conservation-of-energy" class="md-crosslink">first law of thermodynamics</a>, the energy of the universe cannot be decreased. <span id="ref197780"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/information-processing" class="md-crosslink">Information</a>, on the other hand, is negatively entropic; as knowledge, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/technology" class="md-crosslink autoxref">technology</a>, “know-how,” it constantly increases. Research engenders research, and each technological advance multiplies the productive wealth of the world <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/community" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="community">community</a>. Consequently, “Spaceship Earth” is a regenerative system whose energy is progressively turned to human advantage and whose wealth increases by geometric increments.</p><!--[P9]--><p>Fuller’s book <em><span id="ref197781"></span>Nine Chains to the Moon</em> (1938) is an outline of his general technological strategy for maximizing the social applications of energy resources. He further developed this and other themes in such works as <em>No More Secondhand God</em> (1962), <em>Utopia or Oblivion</em> (1969), <em>Operating Manual for Spaceship Earth</em> (1969), <em>Earth, Inc.</em> (1973), and <em>Critical Path</em> (1981).</p><!--[P10]--><span class="md-signature"><a href="/contributor/Robert-W-Marks/1906">Robert W. Marks</a></span><span class="md-signature"><a href="/editor/The-Editors-of-Encyclopaedia-Britannica/4419">The Editors of Encyclopaedia Britannica</a></span></section><!--[END-OF-CONTENT]--></article><div class="md-learn-more extra-content" data-module="learn-more" data-value="learn-more">        <h2>Learn More <span>in these related Britannica articles:</span></h2>        <ul>        <li class="entry">                <a href="/technology/building-construction/High-rise-construction-since-1945#ref260190">                    <div class="image-wrapper text-center">                            				<img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/180x300/22/127022-004-DDEB9FD1.jpg"  alt="construction of apartment buildings" />	</div>                    <div class="title"><strong>building construction: Postwar developments in long-span construction</strong></div>                    <div class="description">…by the architect and engineer <strong>R.
